reviewText: As other reviewers have noted, this DVD is not a core workout, but rather an instructional video for trainers.  That's all well and good, and while the information contained in the film is educational and quite interesting, the aesthetic and formatting components are completely distracting.  It all looks incredibly dated, like something that might have been produced in the 1980s.The information is quite valuable, and I do feel like I learned quite a bit from the instructional point of view (importance of a strong core, proper technique, etc.), however I could not justify paying upwards of $27 when the material is presented in so cheap a fashion.
summary: Not what you might be expecting
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was expecting the CORE STABILITY TRAINING DVD to be along the lines of aP90X: Tony Horton's 90-Day Extreme Home Fitness Workout DVD ProgramorPOWER 90: Tony Horton's Total Body Transformation 90 Day Boot Camp Workout DVDs, both of which I enjoy, but it seems to be more of an instructional video for those who are already working with a physical therapist. However, you can do the exercises yourself but don't expect motivation or reasoning as to why you're doing the specific movement other than to strengthen your core.BTW, your core is your midsection, basically your waist, that includes your abs, lower back and spine. Strengthening this area is important for good posture and to keep injuries to a minimum when partaking in sports or other physical activities.The emphasis is on quality and not quantity, as Dr. Liebenson explains in the introduction, and the video shows you the correct and incorrect way to do the exercises. Running time on the DVD is about 34:25-minutes.You'll need some additional equipment if you plan on doing the entire routine:* Small Medicine Ball (maybe a small weight would work).* Large Exercise Ball.* Leg Band (Looks like a large rubber band that goes around your thighs like this oneCando Band Exercise Loop - 15" Long - Green - Medium).* Balance Sport Trainer (like this oneBosu Sport 55 cm Balance Trainer).* Some Foam Padding (and a stick for balance).I don't have any of these things except for the large exercise ball, but I think you can do the exercises without the medicine ball just use a small light weight, but you'll need the leg band, large exercise ball, and the balance trainer for other exercises because the movement is dependent on those items.Objects magically appear between exercises, like the foam padding that you lie on that's on top of the yoga mat, without any explanation as to why they are there and what they're called. Maybe they're optional?Here are some heads-up about the DVD:* Issues playing on my computer, but it works fine on regular DVD player.* No interaction with the viewer. At times you feel like a voyeur just watching someone doing their physical therapy. It isn't like the P90X DVDs where the instructor, Tony Horton, is doing the exercises with you, while explaining the movements and what they're for.* Not very exciting or motivational.* You can select specific exercises and the DVD will play from there or just start at the beginning and it will automatically continue on from that point.Anyway, I think the DVD is good to help someone who experiences problems following other exercise DVDs because of limited mobility or injury or weak core. The exercises are relatively simple and non-impact, with the focus being on form, so even people who haven't worked out in a long time (or ever) should be able to complete each move. Of course, as with any instructional workout DVD, you should consult your doctor as to whether or not this would be good for you -- especially if you've had a previous injury to your back or spine or are extremely out of shape.If you're looking for a video that shows you the wrong and right way to workout, i.e. using gym equipment, this DVD does provide some instructions on working out at a gym and shows you the improper form to avoid. It goes through some of the more common exercise equipment like the rowing machine or the lat pull down bar, but this section is very short. I would've liked to have more on this topic, especially with a focus on free weights and doing common movements like bicep curls and lunges, and I thought that's what the entire DVD was about, but it isn't.The price is way too high for something that isn't very motivating and is very short. Plus you'll need to buy additional equipment, so it's averages three stars.
summary: You'll Need *Equipment* And This Isn't A Commercial Type Workout DVD!
Title: N/A

reviewText: It is indeed unfortunate that this DVD is not really something one can easily exercise along with. However, there is some very valuable stuff on this DVD, so I intend to use it as a reference.It is great fun to work out with a video; however, I love even more to draw ideas from various sources and piece together my own routines. There's a lot to be said for having things quiet so one can listen to one's body and really focus on form, body sensations of fatigue, energy, etc. (-sometimes joy and wellbeing - to good to miss!) It is particularly enjoyable to  draw from all different sources  on those days when the body feels like a concrete slab and just does not want to move...a little variety can be refreshing and inspiring.Anyway, what I did was to insert a few exercises from the DVD at a time into my exercise sessions over two or three days until I completed the DVD. The next couple of days, I exercised along with the whole DVD, pausing it often in order to work both sides of my body and, of course,  to have enough time to get up and down, get the equipment together, and be sure I really understood the instructions.I was surprised to find that in spite of my bumbling around, when it was all over, my sometimes recalcitrant body felt like a million (perhaps a trillion) dollars...refreshed, balanced, warmed up, singing inside. For me, that is a real selling point.So there is definitely much to be said for the DVD... lots of great stuff there. I don't see as much resemblance to yoga and tai chi as to mat Pilates, though, and I will definitely adapt some of the exercises just a little to make them more flowing and to incorporate some relaxation to balance all that bracing.Definitely recommended as a reference.
summary: Good healthy information to draw from
Title: N/A

reviewText: If your motivation for exercising is to impress others with how much weight you can lift, or how big your muscles are, forget this kind of training.  This DVD does not present a fast track for impressing other people.  And it is not meant to entertain.  It is a scientific approach to safely maximize your bodies fitness to function best in the real world for a full lifetime.  It also can be profitably used to safely recover from sports injuries.I would say that I wish I had this DVD when I was young, but the truth is that in those days I would not have appreciated this approach at all.  In fact, it is only now that I'm in my seventies that I have the wisdom to fully appreciate what this type of training has to offer.  (That's why I gave this review that title.)My goal now is to remain fully active and reduce the pains of aging for as long as possible.  As far as longevity: proper diet, exercise, and rest offers greater potential - but no guarantees.  I don't worry about that.  I expect to die only once.This exercise program will probably seem boring to most young people.  Be advised however, it is not always necessary to grow old to acquire wisdom.  Most of wisdom is just thinking ahead knowing that there exists penalties for carelessness.
summary: TOO SOON OLD - TOO LATE SMART
Title: N/A

reviewText: I think this DVD might be an excellent resource for anyone motivated with pain resulting from injuries. It also may be excellent training for professionals interested in working with patients to increase core stability.The exercises are done slowly, carefully, and methodically. There is lots of attention to detail.I've done Pilates for years and in the past I've bought training materials meant for Pilates instructors working with core stability, etc. Those training materials were a little easier for me to work with because I was doing the exercises as the instructor pointed out the reasons for each one and the cautions as well. In this DVD we are just watching the explanation and demonstration, which is terribly boring unless you are highly motivated for one of the reasons I mentioned above. Otherwise, all you have here is the tedious positioning and alignment for exercises you aren't doing and don't really know why you should.Then again, I know dozens of people who have injured themselves exercising with poor technique, overuse, burning out knees, etc. If this DVD actually gave the viewer an exercise session, maybe with Dr. Liebenson pointing out corrections and improvements in the quality of movements, it might have wider appeal.
summary: A Good Resource For Anyone Interested in Core Stability Training
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video is not what you might expect. The textbook-y cover art is perhaps the first clue. It's very different from all the mass market workout DVDs sold which usually feature impossibly fit women with toned abs and skimpy workout attire. Those videos are designed to let you exercise along to them, featuring trainers that shout out encouragements and good music to workout to. This DVD is not like that. It's basically a textbook on video and is perhaps best aimed at healthcare practitioners.The information is very educational and extensive, but it lacks pizzazz. Narrated by Craig Liebenson, a doctor of chiropractic, the presentation is very straight-forward and lecture-like... maybe something out of a sports medicine or physiotherapy course. While affable and easy to understand, he tends to be pretty dry and no-nonsense. Don't expect any jokes, banter, or asides. It's all business here. The shots are all of a model/actress doing the exercises. Sometimes he's in the shot directing her movements and sometimes it's just the actor.Production quality-wise, the DVD menu is very poorly organized. The menus aren't animated and just look like a giant numbered list. There are 7 pages of chapter listings and no pictures or thumbnail videos to let you quickly find the appropriate chapter at a glance. The entire DVD is about 35 minutes, with over 100 exercises, broken down into 16 major exercise groups. Many of the title cards cards separating chapters just look like fancied up Powerpoint slides. You definitely will not be able to exercise to this video. You have to watch the chapter, remember the exercise, then perform them on your own. It would be helpful to offer a booklet of all the different exercises. There's no insert. My balance ball came with one. This DVD should too.There's a very good intro in which he talks about how we tend to exercise for looks instead of for health (developing superficial muscles instead of core strength, emphasizing quantity of movement over quality), but no closing remarks or words of encouragement/optimism or even credits after the last exercise. It just cuts and goes back to the main menu. The DVD is 1.33 aspect ratio. The DVD length and format is not even listed on the back cover.Overall, a cut and dry informational DVD. It's important information about proper technique and form, but the presentation is dull. If you want something to exercise along to, this is not for you.
summary: Very good information, poor presentation
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a somewhat odd video, in that it is almost a reference guide to exercise as opposed to your more typical "workout" video that guides you through a 1/2 hour or whatever workout.  Basically it shows you an exercises with some pointers on how to do an exercise  (and how not to do it) and then moves on to the next. It is a good set of exercises using various pieces of equipment (fitness ball, foam roller, broomstick, etc) - I would see this as a reference where you pick and choose exercises you want, though do think the DVD would be better if it were the extra for a book that explained more about the exercises and their benefits,
summary: Video reference guide to a set of exercises - not a workout video
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD offers important training guidance for everybody, whether you have low-back issues (as I do) or not. It's like having a good, sound physical therapy program on DVD, ready when you are. The exercises and stretches are clearly demonstrated, and the emphasis on proper technique is excellent; I realized I've been doing some of these exercises wrong. A strong core will improve anybody's fitness, health, energy and quality of life. My only quibble is that DVD menus and presentation are low-tech and a bit unfocused, as if Liebenson didn't put a lot of thought, time or money into it ... yet he charges $27 for the DVD. It would be a good deal at about half that price.
summary: Strong training, weak presentation
Title: N/A

reviewText: Basically this DVD helps you learn how to train your core. It misses the mark by not showing full training routines.Any dvd you buy on to workout with will show you proper movements (if it's a good dvd). I'm not sure who the target audience is for this dvd.It was very poorly produced and seemed dated in it's filming style. Yes you can learn from this DVD but it seems overpriced for what you are getting.
summary: Good basics but very little to gain.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video was not what I expected. I have been using P90X, Insanity and other similar programs that all have core components. I was expecting a guided routine - do this exercise for a minute, followed by the next exercise, etc., all accompanied by a pumping soundtrack and cheesy jokes and motivation. The purpose of this video is to show you a series of exercises, in their proper form, that you or a therapist can then assemble in to a routine of your own.After figuring out that this video was not what I expected, I watched it through. I had all of the equipment required already (exercise ball, stretch bands, weights/medicine ball, yoga mat, and a balance trainer) so I decided to watch it a second time while following along with the exercises. I found the pace to be uneven and the video to be essentially useless as a workout video. The value I did find was in its focus on proper form in every exercise.I went back to my standard core workouts with something of a new appreciation for maintaining form. I ended up watching portions of the Core Stability Training video once or twice more to refresh a couple of points, but as of this point in time I haven't touched it in weeks and don't really plan on it.If you are an instructor, physical therapist or other person working with people recovering from injury or illness, this might be a good product for you. If you are on the market for a good core workout dvd, look elsewhere.
summary: More like an instructional video than a workout DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is not an exercise DVD it is a training tool.All the exercises performed in this film are for core strength and often assigned to individuals requiring physical therapy. These are also exercises that when they are performed in an actual exercise class are often done wrong. Therefore the purpose of this film is to show from both a side and overview angle how these exercises are to be performed correctly to achieve maximum potential and/or to prevent further injury.From a practitioner's point of view this is a great tool to know what to look for in a patient's performance and to be able to correct them. For anyone who just likes to exercise this is a great way to improve your form without having to fork out the big bucks for the expertise of a trainor.
summary: Great tool for PT's, Trainors, patients & anyone who just wants to work out properly
Title: N/A

However, it will not play on my computer (I have a Mac) so I cannot watch it.  Will have to borrow someone's PC to view, but be aware that this is a possibility.  :-(

The information is sound, safe with proper techniques and organized very well.  If you are looking to add certain exercises to your program, this is worthy of consideration.
summary: Great concepts for an instructional DVD.  This is not an exercise video.

The cover and title seem intentionally ambiguous and will no doubt fool many people into buying it thinking it is an instructional workout video.  It is not.  Again, the information is useful, but not what I thought I was getting.

reviewText: I have personally experienced episodes of low back pain and want to prevent engaging in the mistakes that caused this to happen. Therefore this instruction on correct position and alignment is of great importance to me.  The production value is indeed lacking so keep this in mind as you consider a purchase.  Included are health club tips to keep you safe not only at home but in your local gym.  I will continue to use this to enhance my performance and will update as my form improves.
summary: Great instructional DVD on proper workout form...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Core Stability Trainingis a training DVD designed to teach proper form for more than 50 core stability exercises.  This is really ideal for a physical therapist or professional personal trainer.  At the same token, serious fitness enthusiasts can learn a lot from this video.  It is not meant for casual exercise enthusiasts, and it is not meant to be used as an exercise program.  The concepts and exercises that are covered here are meant to be integrated into a full physical therapy or exercise program by a knowledgeable person.While in some ways this is a basic program, there is a lot of information on proper form that seems to be glossed over quite quickly.  That is my main criticism.  The information is organized, but it could be better structured.  And there could have definitely been improvements both in the presentation and emphasis around key points about good form, which is a central concept in avoiding injury.  Dr. Liebenson is clearly knowledgeable and experienced, but as a result may lack some of the showmanship necessary to emphasize key points.Production value is indeed quite low on this DVD.  However, that is of secondary importance to a physical therapy or exercise science professional.  While there are areas for improvement of that aspect, it does not detract from the good content that is included here.  The videos may not be particularly well recorded for today's HD world, but they do provide enough visual information to allow the viewer to learn the proper way to do these exercises.The core exercises are covered in order of difficulty.  That provides the option to work through them as a comprehensive program.  Alternatively, you can choose exercises specific for your program or ailment.  As with any exercise regimen, those who are using this DVD for self-study will usually want to consult a professional about the exercises they are adding to their routine.CONCLUSIONThis is a very informative video that will be useful for the proper audience.  There are some aesthetic problems with the video, but those are minor in nature.  What should be improved is the organization and presentation of key points so that they are properly emphasized.Enjoy.
summary: Core Stability Training DVD - A Good Resource For Physical Therapy, But Could Use Improvements
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can only imagine that the people demonstrating the exercises in this video must have had a very sore left side, and an untouched right side, when filming was complete.  This is an instructional video, not a video that's intended to guide your workout.  There are several exercises and you see three or four reps of each one, then an example of poor form mistakes you might make.  I think the purpose is to watch the video, write down the exercises you want to do, then try them on your own.These are core stability exercises, obviously, drawn primarily from Yoga and Pilates.  Some of these exercises are new to me, so they might be creations of the person who developed the video.  (Or maybe I need to take more classes.)  They assume that you'll have some equipment on hand.  So far I've seen them use a mat,bands, an exercise ball,half and full foam rollers, hand weights (weight unspecified,) a stick (a broomstick would work, I think,) aBosu(one of my favorite balance devices,) and a variety ofmedicine balls.  There may have been other items I forgot about.  I wouldn't buy any of these items before watching the video.  Some of them, like the stick and Bosu, are only used with a partner, and many of them are only used for a couple of exercises.  It may be possible to substitute items around the house for some of this equipment.As others have mentioned, production values are not great.  The video looks like it was shot in a physical therapy office, the music is bland and repetitive, each exercise is one chapter with several seconds of the same graphic to remind you what the name of the exercise is, and it's a little strange to watch the instructor repeatedly poking at the abs of the person demonstrating the exercise, to illustrate tight, engaged core muscles.  The menus are difficult to navigate, at least on my DVD player and my computer, and finding one specific exercise is frustrating and time consuming.  But these are excellent core exercises, explained well, with very good examples of good and bad form.  The introduction explains why good form is necessary.  This isn't a workout video that you'll be using daily.  But it is some very good information about core stability and good form, clearly presented.
summary: Useful information, not a workout video
Title: N/A

reviewText: Don't get me wrong. The information presented here is good and seemingly up to date. It's the marketing and production that are all wrong. This video looks like a cheap informational video shot in someone's home with some cheap video equipment. Not what you would expect for the price.The format of the workout is too technical. You are taught how to perform exercises and even groups of them accurately and protect yourself from injury or at least ineffectiveness by doing it all wrong. That part is good. However, you basically would have to study each workout before attempting to do it.The marketing people didn't do such a hot job defining what the purpose of this video is.On the cover you see the list of different "workouts" along with running times. When I first read that, I thought, "Wow, a 40 minute ab segment - I'm going to be wiped out".  Well, not really. It's only a small amount of actual workout and a whole lot of talk with some demonstration.If you're the kind of person who just wants to learn good technique and do your own thing at that gym, this would be a decent resource, though not well organized.If you're looking for a serious abs workout to do at home, there are plenty of others out there, but this one would get really old, really fast.If you want to learn more about ab training in a scientific, study-then-do-it approach, Paul Chek is pretty much the master in that department. Go to him. He won't steer you wrong. Just may boggle your mind, though.
summary: Not a workout video, and not the greatest instruction, either.
Title: N/A

reviewText: From the description of this DVD, I was expecting a core workout DVD. That is not what this is. This DVD is a physical trainer explaining a long list of different core exercises with a woman demonstrating the exercises. There isn't enough time between exercises to do more than a couple of reps but I don't think there is meant to be. I'm not really sure how this DVD is intended to be used. I guess you would pick out the exercises that work for you and then do them on your own, either memorizing them or finding them on the DVD menu to review the form and then pausing the DVD while you performed the move.Some of the moves require equipment normally found in a physical therapist's office - exercise balls, medicine balls, resistance bands, etc. I think this DVD would actually be a good one for physical therapy students to help them learn the moves to do with their clients because each exercise is broken down in detail and often the wrong way to do the exercise is also shown.The production value of this video is fairly low also. Generic elevator music plays in the background and it looks like it was shot on a camcorder.If you are looking for an typical "Abs of Steel" type workout video then this DVD is not for you.
summary: Not What I Expected from Description
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is a bit misleading in the sense that it is geared towards Physical Therapist or Personal Trainers, rather than a sequenced work out for the general population.  Don't get me wrong, there is some valuable information here. It is just more like watching Dr. Liebenson coach someone rather than addressing the camera.  You almost felt like you are spying on someone's personal training session.  There were times when I felt like "Hey, what about me at home?".The number of exercises he covers is too long to list here (approx. 58) , but I will list the general categories:1. Health Club Tips2. Exercise Basics3. The ABC's of Long Term Athletic Development4. Functional Test5. The Abdominal Brace6. All 4's-Quadruped7. The Side Bridge8. The Dying Bug9. McGill's Abdominal Curl Up10. The Superman11. Hamstring Curls12. Bridges13. The Single Leg Roll Back14. Shoulder/Upper Back Training15. Resisted Core Training16. Functional Core RoutineIn order to do this video you will need additional equipment such as a Bosu, stability ball, foam roller, weights, weighted ball, or partner to provide resistance.  Although the DVD is lengthy, the exercises themselves go very quickly.  I can't see doing this at home as a sequenced work out.  However, I can see trying out some of the exercises at home and then incorporating them little by little into my routine at the gym.Dr. Liebenson does give some good tips here for common mistakes that can hurt you at the gym.  I liked his description of the core as a circular band of support around the back, stomach, and sides which is good way to visualize it when doing any core exercises.  I noticed I even started visualizing this when I was out walking.  He also gives good step by step instruction on proper form for pushups to avoid injury.He refers to Yoga and Pilates exercises such as cat cow, side plank, bridge, and dead bug.  However, he referred to Dead Bug pose several times.  This was a loose variation at best and may be annoying to a Yoga Practitioner.Pro: there is some good information here that can be incorporated into a workout routine.Con: the presentation style which is dated, lengthy, dry, and boring, and geared more for technical instruction to physical therapy or physical trainer students.  The music is also dated.Ultimately, this is more a technical manual than a workout routine.  It would be a good DVD if you are looking to sharpen your skills and form at the gym.  It would be a terrible DVD if you are looking for a sequenced workout to do at home.
summary: Highly Technical and Dry

reviewText: This training was not what I expected but I still thought it was good.  It isn't really a training class you do on the mats and equipment, but instead watch on the couch, and then make sure you incorporate the right way of working out, which is what the video shows you how to do.I don't have some of the equipment you need like the Bosu ball, the leg band, or a medicine ball.I found the information was worthwhile learning and would recommend it to anyone looking for instruction on how to do proper exercises to strengthen your core.  Those looking for an instructor lead workout should look elsewhere.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I love the concept of this video and I wish a lot more fitness teachers would learn and teach proper proper position and alignment. This is an underserved component of the modern fitness movement. I have studied and practiced TaiChi. And have taught Bellydance for many years. Both of these disciplines have a strong core stability component and also focus on proper form, alignment and position (when taught properly).This video focuses on proper alignment for "gym type" exercises that will appeal to people who use modern gyms for their exercise needs, but it will benefit all people who want to develop their core muscles, general balance and knowledge of proper alignment and form.
summary: Practical and Safe Stability Training
Title: N/A
